The EU via the LEONARDO Lifelong Learning Programme and the HEA via PRTLI 4
CELT: Corpus of Electronic Texts: a project of the Department of History, University College, Cork
CELT online at University College, Cork, Ireland.
Available with prior consent of the CELT project for purposes of academic research and teaching only.
This text contains three poems; an Irish one, and two contemporary translations of the same; one into English, the other into Latin.
Jane H. Ohlmeyer (ed.). Political thought in seventeenth-century Ireland: kingdom or colony. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press in association with the Folger Institute, Washington, DC, 2000.
Michelle O'Riordan, Irish Bardic Poetry and Rhetorical Reality (Cork 2007).
The edition used in the digital edition

The electronic text represents the edited text. The ae ligature (with or without fada) has been rendered ae; f with overdot dot has been rendered fh in the electronic text. In the English translation,
was expanded in the electronic text.
Names are not tagged, nor are terms for cultural and social roles.
< state gi=" DIV1" freq=" 1" label=" poem" unit=" number" />
The first poem is in Classical Modern Irish, but the spelling is faulty.
The first translation is in seventeenth-century English.
The second translation is in Neolatin.
Thurneysen's introduction and two footnotes are in French.
File proofed (2); file parsed. SGML and HTML files created.
Introduction and Irish poem typed in and encoded.
English and Latin text typed in and encoded.
Ta mo chroidhe bocht da reabadh,
Ataid a teampla mar barr peine
Gan altoir, gan aiffrionn, gan sleachtuin,
Sdimhin go brach cur cailliodh Eire.
Do bheir buaidh ar shluaite d'einnfhear.
A ngeanamnuigheacht fein ar na treigean
Nil ball dar mballuibh nach bhfuil creachtach.
An calma neartfur sfear a cheachta,
Ta fabharthach, cairdeach lis na Gaedhluibh,
Ag caoine go craite dheiridh na Feine.
Do chaill ar gclairseach a crann gleasta
Ni neart sluaigh, ni hearbuidh beatha,
Siud sinn anois ann sa teallach
Ann a bhfheachtar gach miotal bradach,
Is aisiog ann gach ni dar cailleadh.
Ag so sios suim ar bpeacuidh:
Ar nanam do thabhairt don fhear is measa,
Ba treise ar bhfhiacha na ar dtacar.
Nir frith umlacht choir o aeneach.
Anuair bhi naimhdibh ag dheanamh feadhma,
Cuid a deise aig a bfear is treine.
An trom do cholladh no an mall theisdeacht,
Nach bfuil furtacht a ndan do Ghaeluibh.
Snaib goillionn gearan na nGael ort;
< div1 type=" poem" n=" 2" lang=" en">
My sense benummd, my spirits dead,
I swimme in seas of griefe;
My tears are made my dayly bread,
My heart doth groane, my thoughts bemoan
Noe earthly joy doth shee injoy:
Her pomp and state reducd' to naught,
The ruins of her churches mourne
Noe tongue can tell our woes.
Our pastours fled, the flock disusd',
and none to feed but Thou.
The wolves devoure and slaughter all.
Containe, o God, thy smarting rod,
th speed our wounds that bleed;
Our aged folke, our women, maydes,
Our wealth consumd, our orphans starve
Our lands are wast, and none doe tast
Plague, famine, warre gave us a scarre
And yett, o Lord, they bow is bent;
From top to toe noe place is sound,
each limme hath felt a smart.
The rich, the poore, the lord, the boore,
the weake, the stout, the strong,
The church, the state, and all of late,
The sea alone doth favour us,
By our sad teares that drop to her;
The heavens seeme not to redeeme
The rockes and denns, the woods and fennes
Our quire is mute, our organs dumbe,
our notes both shrill and sharpe;
Untill againe our men from Spaine
Thy sinnes, poore Irland, wrought thy woe;
The fire whereof consumd' thy drosse,
I hope, and made thee pure
and save thee in the end
These were thy hideous, monstrous sinnes:
Thy pride exceeded farre thy strength;
Thy treacherous heart increasd' thy smart,
Noe law could yett unite our hearts;
All power contemnd', noe orders kept;
and Hee will spare the rod.
O Lord of hoastes, accept our votes!
And wee will tell like Israel
Lett faythlesse know your power w
Such as deny and doe defye
And wee that pray to you each day,
Recall, o Lord, our pastours backe;
Confirme us in they heavenly grace;
If Thou forgive, then wee shall live;
If God for us and man gainst us,
< div1 type=" poem" n=" 3" lang=" la">
Languidus emorior; lachrymosas curro per undas,
Pascor et ex lachrimis; fit mihi vita dolor.
Corde dolorifero mea mens deplorat Iernam,
Cujus ab exitio gaudia nulla beant.
Proscripti proceres, pompa et praeciosa sepulta
Post casus Iakob, post tristia fata Judaeae
Nullibi par nostris luctua lingua legit.
Grex sine pastore est, sine pastu. Pastor es unus,
Christe; venito, juva! sternimur ore lupi.
Parcito jam virgis; dura est qua cedimur ira.
Curre, veni, sana vulnera, et ira ruat.
En modo sacra videt prophanari Vesta, tremiscens,
Virgineos Veneris dum videt esse thoros.
Squalida cuncta patent tetris maculata ruinis;
Quae fuerant praetii, trita rejecta jacent.
Vir, mulier, faemella, senex, captiva juventus,
Infantes et opes jam periere simul.
Terra jacet sterilis; nulli dant gaudia messes;
Bella, fames, pestis, quicquid et extat, obest.
Siccine, Christe, tuis pharetris penetramur et arcu,
Undique dum telis corpora nostra rubent.
Dives, inops, dominus, ruralis, fortis et aeger,
Clerus cum populo, portat uterque crucem.
Sola favent pelagus, quia nostris fletibus undans,
Et ventus, nostra voce ululante fremens.
Caetera bella movent: caelum subsidia traxit;
Saxa negant latebras, silva paludis opem.
Organa nostra silent; cythara maesta canit.
Sic sine fine dolor, sine spe tristitia, donec
Ex Iberi redeat tristis et exul Hiber.
Haec ipsi tulimus nobis, mala nostra tulerunt,
Quae nunc expurgat justus in igne deus.
Verte, reverte Syon! Pietas miserebitur olim,
Si tua contrito crimina corde fleas.
Haec tua culpa fuit: furtum, violentia, raptus
Et praeter vires luxus inanis opum.
Tu tibi crudelis, tibi perfida, Banva rebellis,
Dum flerent viduae cum minorenne jugum.
Nullus erat redamantis amans, nulla unio rerum;
Lex sine lege gemens; undique triste chaos.
Prodiga vita fuit, bella intestina, tumultus:
Finis et his nostris Mars, sua bella malis.
Verte, reverte Syon! Tandem tua crimina plangas:
Et feret auxilium, qui tulit ante plagas.
Suspice vota, deus, de pulvere fusa tuorum.
Ut semel ex nostris gloria vestra sonet,
Perfida mens videat qua valeatis ope.
Et nos sancticolo vincimur usque modo.
Et semel emergant spes, amor atque fides.
Si tu condones, vivet; vita esto sepulta:
Si tu pro nobis, mox redivivet Hiber.
